So as I see it, you are liable for and can be sued for your dogs behavior...  See California Code of Civil Procedures 3342(a) - Just google it, you'll find it an eye opening read.

*** Previous Review ***
5 stars because of its convenience ~ that is, there are nights where I don't feel like taking the trusted friend out but know when I walk through my front door she is there a-waiting-n-wagging her big fluffy tail, happy to see me and especially happy because she knows within minutes we'll be on our way.  

So in short, our walks together are the highlight of her day and I hate to disappoint, so Hooray for Huntington Park as its a quick walk up the hill.  I'm happy, the DaWg is happy, and when my nieces come to visit, they're happy too.  

Yes, this park is more for the kiddies, but allows the doggies to play too.  And on nice warm sunny days you can find most people parked on benches sun worshipping as they read (or snooze) while their precious pooch plays with other pooches.  

I hear that Thursday night there is a happy hour; suppose this is an excuse for me to drop by Le Beau before heading up and bring a bottle of vino on our next trip up the hill.  

Fridays are certainly happy hour, and not the kind of happy hour that you and I participate in.  But it is certainly happy hour for the pooches.  I was amazed how many folks, before heading out to dinner, etc., bring the pooches out for play.  It was certainly happy hour for the pooches and all played well together, rolling in the wet grass, and playfully bouncing on and off the benches, chasing one another all over the park.  Too darned cute is all I can say.
author: Cris B.

description: In 1872, Gen. David D. Colton built one of the most elaborate residences in the city on this site. After his death in 1878, his widow closed the house, then sold it five years later to Central Pacific railroad exec Collis P. Huntington, who resided in it with his wife until he passed away in 1900.  She remained in it until it was destroyed by the quake and fire of 1906. In 1915, Mrs. Huntington donated the land to the city with the stipulation it forever be a park. The classic square forms the heart of Nob Hill, and its many benches provide a place to catch your breath after the grueling hike up the California Street hill. The Fountain of the Tortoises, replicating one in Rome, features cavorting turtles and nymphs and is lit by eight underwater lamps that, during the holidays, are changed from clear to red, amber, and green. Since the late 1970s, the park has been overseen by the Nob Hill Association.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Kind of a surprising place to find in the middle of Nob Hill. While small, it is nicely maintained and features an interesting fountain. 

I imagine it as a nice urban oasis for Nob Hillinites.
author: Matthew C.

description: You should go up to the park while they have the Xmas lights up! This is not my favorite park in San Francisco (that'd be alamo square) but I am happy enough to live a block away from one of the centers of San Francisco and I never take it for granted - every time I set foot in this park it feels like the first time to me. I love my neighborhood and can't imagine living anywhere else.
author: Darren M.

description: As a Nob Hill Association member, I am very proud of our neighborhood park. My dog and I enjoy spending time there!  I wish more visitors would respect our leash laws, and pick up the poop...
author: Maven G.

description: It's funny the dog person said the tourists are obnoxious, because I think the dog people are kind of so. But not so much that it taints the Huntington Park experience in any way. It's a very clean, unique and intimate urban park with the towering cathedral on one side and the old Flood Mansion on the other. I like this place in the late afternoon and evening, especially toward Summer and Fall when the sides of the buildings downtown reflect the golden sunset. Sit on one of the benches and meditate on the fountain in the center, then stroll over to Grace Cathedral and walk the labyrinth. Then come back and pet some dogs.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: It can get awfully windy and cold here, but when the weather is that exceptionally blue, warm and sunny, relax here after going to Grace Cathedral and enjoy the peace and quiet. Hear the cable cars in the distance and experience the simple beauty.
author: miriam b.

description: I absolutely love this place.  Located right on top of Nob Hill, it's the perfect berth to view multiple SF institutions 360 degrees around: the California cable car, Grace Cathedral, the Fairmont and Mark Hopkins hotels, the Masonic Auditorium, and let's not forget the views of the City to the south and east.  I don't know any SF park with as many benches per square foot.  So you're almost guaranteed a place to sit and relax.  It's the best on those warm SF days with the sun glowing and fountain flowing .
author: M A N I K.

description: I love playing on the swings at one am when it squeeks and sounds like drowning cats.  It scares everyone.  I like to sit on the grass and watch people as they try to parallel park their oversize cars in spaces too small.  I like walking by early late winter mornings and watch the people practice tai chi as the blossoms shed petals that descend diagonally, floating and rising, floating and rising, cut only by the slow and purposeful movements of people.
author: Tangerine L.

description: Not as good as alta plaza, but the doggies are great (if you are into small dogs) and it's a great place for Academy of Art University kids that stay in the local dorms to go and get high at night.
author: Moi S.

description:
My dogs' morning walk includes a stroll through this park.  It's gorgeous with the Christmas lights up!

Only one criticism: I wish there was a gated area for the dogs to run around in.  :)
author: Leslie R.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite places in the city on a sunny Sunday afternoon. Quaint little park that is an oasis in the middle of Nob Hill. 

If you are a dog lover, then come here. There is always a slough of friendly dogs that are running around. This past Sunday, there was an art show with local artists. Well kept and with a nice fountain. I could sit there all day and listen to mix of relaxing water and city drone.
author: Matt K.

description: This is my jam! I get my fix for dog dog dog everything here. Sometimes I affix raw bacon to my socks so the cute crazy ones will run after me. That's a lie. I have a job and bacon ankles are officially not allowed.
author: Shannon V.

description: Cool. This park has a comfy gray wall around it that is perfect for sitting on for hours. I sat here for 2 hours trying to get a glimpse of Bono, who I heard was staying at the Huntington Hotel. Lo and behold right before I left, I met him. He was so nice too! He signed my CD that I had brought and took a photo with me. The bellhop of the Huntington Hotel took it with my camera. He had no idea who Bono was, nor U2 (lol wow). COOL!!!!!! Nice park to play Gameboy for 2 hours.. Yes.. this was back in my GAMEBOY days in 9th grade.
author: O K.

description: Gorgeous park surrounded by some of the oldest and most reknowned hotels in San Francisco and Grace Cathedral.  Beautiful white lights fill the trees at night.  Great romantic spot to swing on the swings at night and great daytime spot to go read a book or have a picnic.  I'm so glad I live so close!
author: Vanessa Z.

description: Beautiful park in the midst of all the hustle and bustle of town on top of Nob Hill. Every once a year, the California Mille http://www.californiamille.com/ is held in front of the Fairmont Hotel and in/around the Park! Comprehensive array of classic, vintage, collector cars on show. When the weather is warm, there are also art exhibits for sale.
author: Yan M.

description: I used to love coming here with my cousins and his friends when we were little . It was our favorite park . I used to come here for school field trips too . I loved the swings . My classmates / cousins and I would push each other on the swings or we would swing ourselves to get higher . We would always race each other to see who got higher first . It's nice because when you get high enough you get a nice view of the Hilton haha . I like this park .. it's very pretty , refreshing , and quiet .
author: Eileen L.

description: This is one of the neatest parks in the city.  With plenty of comfortable benches, it's like sitting on top of the world.  It's even quiet up here since not so many cars come up the hill unless they have to.  It's a great place to hang out on a warm day talking with a friend, playing frisbee, football, catching up with your cell phone calls or just enjoying the architecture, views and seeing the dogs and kids play on the playground.
author: P H I L H.

description: My relaxation area. It's great on sunny days and it's just so beautiful watching all the kids and their parents. I grew up playing at this park. The floral arrangements are adequate, the atmosphere is great! If there is any problem with the play structures, it's fixed within the week. The breezes are wonderful!
author: Jenny L.

description: On a sunny day, nothing beats sitting on a bench in Huntington Park, reading a good book or the Sunday newspaper, watching the cute dogs run playfully by, listening to the bells chime at Grace Cathedral, and thanking your lucky stars that you live in such a beautiful city.
author: Ava S.

description: One of the cleanest parks in the City.  I have a lot of good memories here.  My best friend lives in Nob Hill and we sometimes head down here with a cup of coffee and chat for hours.  It's a very nice place to spend some quality time with a good friend.
author: Kayte M.

description: Dog-watching on a sunny Saturday afternoon! Climb the killer hill, sit on a bench around the fountain, pretend to read, and drool all over the puppies running around you. A little Snob Hill attitude on certain dogs and dog-owners, but absolutely passable. Very neighborhood-y, very feel-good. You'll forget you're in a city!
author: G. J.

description: This is my favorite park in the city, because it is so urban and gorgeous. The marble dolphin fountain is beautiful, and the view is spectacular it makes you realize how worth it it is to pay outrageous rents to live here. It is San Francisco in every respect, with the cable cars clanging down the street, the view of the Bay Bridge, and its position atop Nob Hill with Flood Mansion and Grace Cathedral at both angles. It is so fun to people watch too, and the surrounding architecture is some of the best in the city.
author: T W.

description: Lots of dogs, lots of kids, lots of people, lots and lots of activities (churches, hotels, cable cars, fountain, art shows). Me likey! It's not a huge park, but great between lunch hour and sunset. Hard to find a great doggie-friendly place. ;P
author: May S.

description: I work near Union Square and hike up the several blocks of STEEP hill regularly to eat lunch at this park. Walking up Taylor Street, you get to use the stairs that are built into the sidewalk, so that's a plus. This is a tiny, one-block park, with a lot of things going for it. First of all, for a lunch-breaker like myself, looking for a nice bench to sit on -- this park has dozens of benches. Which works well for how varied the weather can be. If it's cold, you can find somewhere to sit in the sun, and if it's warm and you're exhausted from hiking up the hill, there are benches in the shade. I don't like sharing a bench, and I've never had to, since there are so many. Then there is a big fountain in the middle of the park and some swing sets in the back. I haven't tried swinging yet... there usually are children back there with their parents. The grassy middle sections of the park are highly kept up, with everything looking perfect and maintained. On sunny days there are often a handful of people laying in the grass working on their tans, and on any day, there are a surprising number of people walking their micro-dogs in that park. I've never seen so many tiny dogs consistently in one location. It's a great people-watching park... most folks seem to be moderately affluent locals who probably live there on Nob Hill. (I've never seen a homeless person there, although I've never seen any police or security there either.) The view includes California Street and the cable cars, Grace Cathedral, the big hotels (Fairmont, Mark Hopkins, etc.), some great other historic architecture, and then also, when you look towards the east you can see the Bay Bridge. The perimeter of the park has some really pretty light-pink rose bushes, and are gorgeous when they're in bloom. It's just a delightful lunch spot, and worth the hike up there!
author: Zoe H.

description: also in my top five favorite places in san francisco, i love this park.  i think it is perfect.  ideal for a sunday afternoon sit down with a good book and a cup of coffee, it would also be an ideal setting for a visit with a friend or just a quick stroll.  it's always clean and well kept, the fountain in the center gives the park a balanced and classic feel.  grace cathedral overlooks the park and is indeed a sight to rest the eyes on.  it is also surrounded by a wonderful display of classic hotels and beautiful apartment buildings.  it's a little piece of new york here in the city and it is lovely.
author: Steven K.

description: I grew up playing in this park. As a child you don't appreciate all that surrounds this park. Now I look back and smile.
author: Kacey K.

description: i simply cannot imagine anyone giving this fewer than 5 stars. top of nob hill. beautiful by nite & day, 365 days/year. even in the pouring january rain!
author: O B.
